case_vignette: A 66-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of a new skin lesion on his hand. He is concerned because the lesion has grown rapidly over the previous 2 weeks. He endorses traumatizing the area and notes that there was some bleeding. His past medical history is significant for chronic renal failure for which he received a renal transplant 5 years prior, as well as multiple surgeries for skin cancers. His current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, prednisone, tacrolimus, and mycophenolate mofetil. Physical exam is notable for a 2 x 2.5 cm nodular lesion of the dorsal hand (Figure A).
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a new skin bump on my hand that has been getting bigger quickly over the last two weeks, and it even bled a little after I hurt it.
Do you have any other similar bumps on your body?
No, I just have this one new bump on my hand.
Have you had any recent trauma or injury to your hand?
Yes, I injured the area where the bump is and it did bleed.
Do you have a history of skin conditions or skin cancer in your family?
I've had several surgeries for skin cancer myself.
Based on your symptoms and medical history, it's important to see a doctor for further evaluation. I would recommend seeing a dermatologist as soon as possible.

Yes, I've had several surgeries for skin cancers and I also have a history of chronic kidney failure.
